article.title: Age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment are attenuated by lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise
article.abstract: Age-related loss of skeletal muscle mass and function, referred to as sarcopenia, is mitigated by lifelong calorie restriction as well as exercise.

sections.introduction: Skeletal muscle is crucial for stability, mobility and whole body metabolism. As with all other organs, aging has a detrimental impact on skeletal muscle that can be observed phenotypically as atrophy, susceptibility to damage, fibrosis, and weakness.
sections.methods: Male Fischer-344 rats were purchased from Harlan (Indianapolis, IN) at 10â€“11 weeks of age.
sections.results: Fiber cross-sectional area (CSA) in the plantaris muscles was quantified following Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E) staining.
sections.discussion: In the current study, we report that lifelong mild (8%) caloric restriction (CR) and CR plus lifelong voluntary wheel running (WR) are interventions capable of partially preventing the age-associated decrease in plantaris muscle fiber cross-sectional area (CSA).

experimental_factors.treatment: 8% caloric restriction, 8% caloric restriction + wheel running
experimental_factors.treatment_raw: 8% caloric restriction, 8% caloric restriction + wheel running

article.insights_summary: Lifelong caloric restriction and voluntary exercise can attenuate age-related alterations in the sarcolemmal environment, leading to improved muscle function and overall health.
article.acknowledgments: Research reported in this publication was supported by grants from NIH (AR054084), NASA (NNX12AR62G), the Sydney and J.L. Huffines Institute, and the Strategic Research Award.
